speaker: Niles
text: Is it me or is the foam a tad dense today?

speaker: Frasier
text: Like a dreary fog on a Scottish moor.

speaker: Niles
text: Rather than accent it overwhelms.  Rather than flirt it assaults.

speaker: Martin
text: [_annoyed_] Rather than watching the ballgame I have to listen to this.  [_Roz comes over to join them._]

speaker: Roz
text: Hey, you guys.

speaker: All
text: Hey, Roz.

speaker: Roz
text: Frasier, don't forget your staff meeting tomorrow.  It starts at...  [_A man comes and sits down at the nearby table.  Roz just stops talking and can't take her eyes off him._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I certainly hope his tailor can fix the two holes you've just burned in his jacket!

speaker: Roz
text: They're not in his jacket!  It starts tomorrow at ten.  Hey, Marty.  What are you doing here?

speaker: Martin
text: They're dragging me out to buy some new clothes.

speaker: Niles
text: We're taking him out to Rodolfo's once-a-year sale.  It's fifty per cent off.  Alterations are free.

speaker: Martin
text: Big deal.  "Bud's Clothing" do that every day.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, not to mention the convenience of getting your "BigFoot" pizza right next door.

speaker: Martin
text: These guys think I have bad taste in clothes.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, I like the way you dress.

speaker: Niles
text: I believe that's what's called "the clincher."  Shall we go?

speaker: Martin
text: [_getting up_] All right.  Well I'll just hit the head and we can get it over with.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad, you could show a little more enthusiasm.

speaker: Martin
text: OK. [_fake enthusiasm as he goes inside the Caf e_] Gee, I can't wait to hit the head and we can get it all over with.  [_Roz is still busy staring at the guy across the table which Niles notices._]

speaker: Niles
text: Are you quite finished undressing him with your eyes?

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, please.  I'm already looking for my stockings and trying to remember where I parked my car.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gesturing at another guy_] You know Roz, I would have thought that the gentleman over there with the flannel shirt would have been more your type.

speaker: Roz
text: Him?  Not a chance.  See the way he's slurping his orange juice?  Sloppy kisser!  You can tell right away the guy's no good I bed.  So cautious.  Look at the way he's blowing on his coffee.  [_Meanwhile Niles is, needless to say, blowing on his coffee and notices Frasier and Roz staring at him._]

speaker: Niles
text: I wasn't trying to cool it.  I was simply blowing a foam hole.

speaker: Roz
text: You don't even wrinkle the sheets, do you?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking across the street_] Niles, that man across the street at the newsstand.  Is that who I think it is?

speaker: Niles
text: He does look familiar.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's T.H. Houghton!

speaker: Niles
text: No!

speaker: Frasier
text: Just think back to the picture on the dust cover of "Time Flies Tomorrow."  A little older, greyer.

speaker: Roz
text: "Time Flies Tomorrow" -- I read that in high school.  What else did he write?

speaker: Frasier
text: Nothing.  That's the crux of his entire legend.  The man published one masterpiece and in the thirty years since he's become a virtual recluse.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh my God.  It is T.H. Houghton.  We're a stone's throw away from one of the giants of American literature.

speaker: Roz
text: Not the way you throw!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, this is incredible.  The man's entire life is shrouded in mystery and there he is.

speaker: Niles
text: I've always idolised him.  What I wouldn't give to meet that man.

speaker: Roz
text: Well why don't you go over and introduce yourself?

speaker: Niles
text: I can't just walk up to a God like that.

speaker: Roz
text: Well find a subtler way.

speaker: Niles
text: In your vernacular that would be what?  To slingshot your panties across the street?

speaker: Roz
text: Foam Blower!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_separating the two_] Niles, she happens to be right.  How often do we get an opportunity like this?  Come on.  Let's go.

speaker: Niles
text: All right.  [_Martin comes back out of the Caf e._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, come on.  We're going.

speaker: Martin
text: Why, what's the rush?

speaker: Niles
text: T.H. Houghton is across the street.

speaker: Martin
text: Who?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pushing Martin as fast as he can_] Come on.  Let's go.

speaker: Martin
text: Hey!  Guy with a cane here!  **IN ANOTHER PART OF THE FOREST...**  [_Scene 2 -- A Nearby Bar. Niles, Frasier and Martin pile into a bar.  Niles and Frasier are arguing._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I thought you said you saw Houghton come in here.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, I'm sorry if my tracking skills aren't up to your standard.  Perhaps instead of asking for a baby brother you should have asked for a German shorthaired Pointer.

speaker: Frasier
text: I did!  Well, I'm sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: He must still be out on the street.  Let's go.

speaker: Martin
text: I'm parking it here.  They've got the Mariners game on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, Dad.  Please.  We can't waste time.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh let him be.  He's dead weight.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  [_Frasier and Niles charge back out in search for Houghton.  Meanwhile an old man comes from the other side of the bar and sits down next to Martin.  It is obvious that this is going to be T.H. Houghton._]

speaker: Houghton
text: What's the score?

speaker: Martin
text: Four to three, Mariners. Both: [_watching the game_] Awww!

speaker: Martin
text: I mean, that's the cut-off man!

speaker: Houghton
text: Can you believe that man makes seven million a year?

speaker: Martin
text: That's crazy.  See him scratching his butt?  That's about five grand a year right there!

speaker: Houghton
text: [_laughing to the barman_] Let me have a Ballantine.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, make it two.  [_They both continue to watch the game together.  The scene SWITCHES to later on and Houghton and Martin are sitting at a table after the game talking._]

speaker: Houghton
text: So that's your favourite character, really?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I really like him.  He's the kind of guy you can just sit and have a beer with.

speaker: Houghton
text: Well, I can see you saying that about "Hoss."  But Little Joe?

speaker: Martin
text: Well that's the great thing about "Bonanza."  There's something for everyone.  [_Frasier and Niles come into the bar with Frasier looking exasperated._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well thank you, Mr. False Alarm. [_imitating Niles_] Oh, look. There he is over at the yoghurt store.  Oh look.  There he is at the futon store.  Oh look.  There he is with Dad.  [_Frasier and Niles suddenly see that he is with Martin and look completely taken aback.  Meanwhile over at the table Houghton is getting up to go._]

speaker: Niles
text: And now he's leaving.  I must tell him what an impact his book has made on my life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Aren't you afraid it will sound just a bit unoriginal?

speaker: Niles
text: Why?

speaker: Frasier
text: Because I'm going to say it first.  [_Niles and Frasier rush over to T.H. Houghton.  Before they can get there another patron from the bar gets in before them._]

speaker: Patron
text: Excuse me, Mr. Houghton?

speaker: Houghton
text: Yeah.

speaker: Patron
text: I just wanted to tell you that...

speaker: Houghton
text: My book changed your life.  Swell.

speaker: Patron
text: No, no.

speaker: Houghton
text: It changed mine too.  Look, I'm sorry, I don't like to discuss my work.  [_He leaves._]

speaker: Patron
text: Well, that was humiliating.  I've never felt so rejected in my life.

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, now.  Don't take it so hard.  Who was to know you'd be so sensitive?

speaker: Patron
text: Hey, aren't you Dr. Frasier Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_walking away from him_] Not now, I don't have the time.  I'm sorry. [_joins Martin at the table_] Dad, do you realise who you were just talking to?  That was T.H. Houghton.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, I know.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, what did you two talk about?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I don't know.  This and that.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, virtually nothing is known about this man.  Can't you give us something specific?

speaker: Martin
text: It was just guy stuff, you know?  Baseball, TV shows, old war stories.

speaker: Frasier
text: He told war stories?

speaker: Martin
text: No, I did.  I told him about the time I made the stew and the platoon got sick.

speaker: Frasier
text: How could you?

speaker: Martin
text: He liked it.  He's a nice guy.  I think maybe I'll buy one of his books.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not books, Dad.  Book.  Book.  He wrote one book and then never wrote again.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, if only we'd arrived ten minutes earlier.  We could have been talking to him.  Could have that explored that mammoth intellect.

speaker: Frasier
text: Can you imagine the torture the man's endured to peak at such an early age?

speaker: Niles
text: [_notices a beermat on the table_] Oh my God, Frasier.  Look. It's a doodle.

speaker: Frasier
text: Not just any doodle.  It's a Houghton doodle.  It's mine.

speaker: Niles
text: It's mine. [_fights over it with Frasier_]

speaker: Martin
text: It's mine.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, what do you care?

speaker: Martin
text: I mean I drew it.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_handing it to Niles_] Well that's very touching.  Here Niles, this is for you.  [_Scene 3 -- The Elevator. Frasier and Niles are going up to Frasier's apartment in the elevator._]

speaker: Niles
text: I don't know when I've enjoyed an exhibit more.  The artist's choice to make that still-life a monochrome was a stroke of genius.  Conveyed such despair.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_deep in thought_] Yes.  It was so refreshing to see a sad peach.

speaker: Niles
text: How about that curator?

speaker: Frasier
text: Kind of a peach herself, wasn't she?

speaker: Niles
text: No cubism there, I don't think.  [_The elevator doors open outside Frasier's apartment.  Martin and T.H. Houghton are waiting to go down.  Niles and Frasier only notice Martin at first._]

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, boys.

speaker: Both
text: Hi, Dad. [_both notice that T.H. Houghton is getting on the elevator with Martin and are momentarily lost for words._]

speaker: Martin
text: Oh Ted, I'd like you to meet my sons.  This is Frasier and Niles.  They're big fans of yours.

speaker: Houghton
text: Hi, guys.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr Houghton... er... we...

speaker: Niles
text: Words can't express... [_totally flabbergasted_]

speaker: Houghton
text: I guess not.  Nice meeting you folks. [_the elevator door closes_]

speaker: Niles
text: We missed them again. [_presses the lift button and the doors open_]

speaker: Martin
text: What's going on?

speaker: Niles
text: That's odd.  So where are you two going?

speaker: Martin
text: Well, Ted's taking me out to this Bratwurst place he knows.

speaker: Frasier
text: Bratwurst.  Yummee.  My God, that's our favourite.

speaker: Houghton
text: Nice meeting you.  [_The elevator door closes once more.  Niles, not content, hits the elevator button again and the door opens again.  Houghton looks puzzled while Martin just looks annoyed._]

speaker: Houghton
text: What's wrong with this thing?

speaker: Niles
text: Could be broken.  Well maybe if you came into the apartment we could call down to the front desk...

speaker: Martin
text: NO! [_pushing Niles away with his cane_] I'm sure it'll work this time!  [_The elevator door closes for the last time.  Niles looks despondent and follows Frasier into his apartment.  Daphne is busy cleaning._]

speaker: Frasier
text: What the hell was he doing here?

speaker: Niles
text: We might know if you hadn't spent an hour pondering the despair of the peach.

speaker: Frasier
text: This from the man who spent thirty minutes looking at "Woman with a rectangular head."

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, was Mrs. Foster in the lobby again?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Daphne.  Could you explain to me just how T.H. Houghton ended up in my apartment?

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, he's only in town for a couple of days.  He doesn't know too many people so he looked your father up, gave him a ring and Mr. Crane invited him over to watch the Mariners game.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_gobsmacked_] He was here all afternoon?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.  It's a shame you couldn't be here.  He told the most fascinating stories.  Of course he and your father are getting on like old chums, but the sweetest thing was how he took to Eddie.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_clearly at his wits' end_] He spent time with Eddie?

speaker: Daphne
text: Fed him his afternoon biscuit.

speaker: Frasier
text: Will the madness ever end?  [_Frasier walks off to the kitchen.  Niles rushes after him._]

speaker: Niles
text: Now, now, let's not give up hope.  Maybe Dad will bring him back to the apartment after dinner.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, well I doubt it.  He'll probably run into J.D. Salinger and Salman Rushdie -- go out for Margaritas.  You know, Niles, these near misses are just excruciating.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_unseen in the living room_] There you go, Mr. Houghton. You're welcome.  [_Frasier and Niles look up before tearing through to the living room. Daphne has just said goodbye._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Was that him?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.  He forgot his coat.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_charging out the front door with Niles in hot pursuit_] Hold the elevator!  [_The elevator door has just closed.  Niles and Frasier collapse against it in despair._]

speaker: Niles
text: We missed him again.  [_Eddie runs out to the hall and sits down in front of Niles and Frasier._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you dare gloat, you miserable little biscuit whore!  [_End of Act 1_]  [_Act 2_]  **QUESTION: HOW DID BABE RUTH CHANGE MUSICAL THEATER HISTORY?**  [_Scene 1 - Frasier's Apartment. Daphne is lying back on the couch reading, eating peanuts and having a drink.  Eddie is keeping watch at the front door and suddenly barks. Daphne quickly gets up, pours what's left of her peanuts into her pocket, downs her drink, puts the glass in the other pocket, pulls out a cloth and begins dusting the table.  By now Eddie has assumed his position in Martin's chair.  Frasier wanders in and sees Daphne "hard at work"._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Afternoon, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Hello. [_throws Eddie a biscuit_] Good dog!  Oh, Dr. Crane. It's a good thing you're home.  Mr. Houghton is dropping by to pick your father up for the Mariners game.

speaker: Frasier
text: You serious?  He's coming back?

speaker: Daphne
text: Yes.  Any minute.  It's a double header. [_Frasier looks blankly at her_] They play two games!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh right, right.  This is incredibly good fortune.  I finally get to spend some time alone with the man, even if just for a few minutes.  [_The doorbell rings._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, be a dear and stall Dad, will you?  If he gives you any trouble just hide his cane.  [_Frasier opens the door full of expectation but is greeted by Niles instead._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  What fortuitous timing.  Er... you know the wine shop just called a moment ago?  It seems they're down to their last two cases of the '82 Chambolle-Musigny, so why don't you dash right down there and stack it all up?

speaker: Niles
text: Okay. [_just as the door is about to shut on him_] Hold it! [_looks suspiciously at Frasier_] You know very well that in 1982 there was a drought in Bourgogne.  The locals dubbed it "The Year of the Raisin."  And that wine was never sold by the case, only by the bottle [_forces his way in_] T.H. Houghton is here, isn't he?

speaker: Frasier
text: No.

speaker: Niles
text: Fine.  Then you won't mind if I just hang around for a while.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, all right.  He's on his way.  He and Dad are going to a baseball game.  It's a double header. [_Niles looks blankly at him_] They play two games!

speaker: Martin
text: [_emerging from his bedroom_] Hi, Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Dad.  So I hear that Mr. Houghton is on his way over. Maybe we could all have lunch before you head off.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, that's a splendid idea.

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, game starts in 45 minutes.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, then perhaps he could come by after the game for a drink.

speaker: Martin
text: Nah, sorry.  That won't work either.  He's got to go to his publisher's.  Drop off his new book.

speaker: Frasier
text: Houghton has a new book?

speaker: Niles
text: [_stunned_] I've lost the feeling in my legs!

speaker: Frasier
text: Did he say anything about it?  The characters?  The setting?

speaker: Martin
text: No.  He just said it was a book.

speaker: Niles
text: Dad!  You have to skip the game.  It's not just for our benefit.  After all, it's baseball.  The man must be starved for intellectual stimulation.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, I know what you're saying -- that someone like that would have to prefer spending time with you than some dumbbell like me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad -- you're not dumb.  You miss the point entirely!  Look, let's just say, for example, you came home one afternoon and I was sitting here discussing literature with... oh, I don't know.  Give me the name of a baseball player.

speaker: Martin
text: Darryl Strawberry.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, a real one!

speaker: Martin
text: Frasier, the problem is, you push too hard.  We just talk sports, have a few laughs.  That's all.  I don't ask him about his work -- that's probably why he told me about the book.  [_The doorbell rings and Frasier goes to answer pondering Martin's words.  It's T.H. Houghton._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Houghton.  Hello.

speaker: Houghton
text: Hi.  How you doing?

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, Ted.  Come on in.

speaker: Frasier
text: So you two boys are off to the baseball game, huh?  Double header.

speaker: Niles
text: [_proudly_] That's two games!

speaker: Houghton
text: Yeah.

speaker: Niles
text: Little known fact about baseball: the owner of the Boston Red Sox sold Babe Ruth to the New York Yankees to finance a Broadway musical, "No No Nanette"

speaker: Houghton
text: [_after a period of silence_] You ready, Marty?

speaker: Martin
text: Let's go.

speaker: Frasier
text: I really enjoyed chatting with you.  Maybe you could drop back by after the game.  We could pick up where we left off...  [_Frasier's words are left trailing as Martin and Houghton leave._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sarcastically_] No No Nanette!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm sorry.  There are exactly two things that I could possibly add to a baseball conversation.  That, and... no, just the one.  [_Both Frasier and Niles collapse on the sofa and lie back._]

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: Have you noticed how Houghton always carries a satchel with him wherever he goes?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually as a matter of fact I have.

speaker: Niles
text: And didn't Dad mention that Houghton was on his way to his publisher's after the game with a new manuscript?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_bored_] Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: And would that be the very same satchel, which is now resting under my head?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God!  [_Frasier and Niles both leap up to see that Houghton has indeed left his manuscript on the arm of the sofa.  They run up and Niles is about to examine it._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Wait!

speaker: Niles
text: Should we?

speaker: Frasier
text: We shouldn't.

speaker: Niles
text: Could we live with ourselves if we did?

speaker: Frasier
text: Could we live with ourselves if we didn't?

speaker: Niles
text: Could we live with ourselves either way?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, stop it, Niles.  Who are we kidding?  [_Frasier makes a grab for the manuscript but Niles stops him and pulls the manuscript delicately out of the satchel.  Frasier goes and checks the front door.  Niles has already placed the manuscript on the table and ever so slowly pulls the cover off._]

speaker: Frasier
text: "The Chameleon's Song," by T.H. Houghton.

speaker: Niles
text: These are hand-written corrections.  Frasier -- this is his original manuscript!  [_Daphne walks out from the bedroom._]

speaker: Daphne
text: Shame on you! [_Frasier and Niles both look extremely guilty_] Going through someone else's personal property!  Well, it's just plain wrong and I know your father wouldn't approve. Of course I wouldn't be here to tell him if I had the day off...

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine, go.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_grabbing her jacket_] Great!  Although having a day off is pretty meaningless when you have no money to, you know, maybe go to lunch or do some shopping, perhaps take in a show... [_takes money off Frasier as she walks past and out the door_] Oh, thanks!

speaker: Frasier
text: All right, Niles.  Shall we?

speaker: Niles
text: Not yet.  The atmosphere has to be absolutely perfect.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good point. [_goes to the light dimmer switch_] Let's begin with the lighting.

speaker: Niles
text: Warmer. [_Frasier turns the switch a tad_] Warmer. [_Frasier turns again_] A little cooler. [_Frasier turns again_] A touch warmer. [_Frasier turns again_] A hair back. [_Frasier gives up and goes over to the drinks cabinet whilst Niles, still concentrating on the lighting keeps on talking_] No, no, a hair the other way.  No, a touch warmer.  Perfect.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_from the drinks cabinet_] Good!

speaker: Niles
text: Ooh excellent, excellent.  What wine would most enhance the experience?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, Niles.  Wine might dull our faculties.  Perhaps instead a slow sipping cordial would be the proper garnish.

speaker: Niles
text: Sherry?

speaker: Frasier
text: Armagnac.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, well see?  That's why you're the older brother.  [_Frasier pours himself and Niles a glass and both sit down at the table with the manuscript in front of them._]  [_The scene SWITCHES to a little later and both are engrossed in the story._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_nearly crying_] Ooh!

speaker: Niles
text: What is it?

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't think you're there yet.

speaker: Niles
text: [_after a pause, then nearly crying_] Ooh!  [_The scene SWITCHES to later still and Frasier and Niles are both finishing the story.  They sit back gobsmacked._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... it's a masterpiece.  [_Eddie, who is standing at the front door, barks._]

speaker: Niles
text: Eddie! [_to Frasier_] I never thought I'd utter these words but it actually surpasses "Time Flies Tomorrow."  [_Eddie, still at the front door, barks twice._]

speaker: Frasier
text: [_annoyed_] Eddie, please!  I'm trying to savour the moment.  [_Eddie suddenly dashes off and, needless to say, the front door opens as Martin and Houghton enter.  Frasier and Niles quickly go about trying to hide the evidence and put the manuscript back in the satchel but are caught._]

speaker: Niles
text: [_innocently_] How was the game?

speaker: Houghton
text: Is that my manuscript?

speaker: Martin
text: What the hell's going on?

speaker: Houghton
text: You went through my bag?  That's my personal property.

speaker: Martin
text: I don't believe you two.

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Houghton, please.  We are terribly, terribly sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: The temptation to read it was just too great.

speaker: Martin
text: What's that supposed to mean?  You're grown men, both of you.  At least I thought you were.  You had no right to touch that.  Ted, I'm sorry.  I'm just so ashamed.

speaker: Houghton
text: Marty, it's all right.

speaker: Martin
text: No, it's not all right.

speaker: Houghton
text: No, no, it's OK.  Really.  Somebody had to read it first. So what did you think?

speaker: Niles
text: Of the book?

speaker: Houghton
text: No, of my typing.  Yes, of course of the book.

speaker: Niles
text: Well... s'great.

speaker: Frasier
text: Er... Wow!

speaker: Houghton
text: Well, at least you liked it.  I'm going to have to be running.

speaker: Martin
text: Are you sure?  I was going to make some coffee.

speaker: Houghton
text: No, no.  I got an appointment.  Can I use the...

speaker: Martin
text: [_pointing towards the bathroom_] Right there.  [_Houghton goes into the bathroom while Martin looks angrily at the boys._]

speaker: Martin
text: Boy, I've had it with you guys.  If you were "Hoss" and Little Joe, Ben Cartwright would kick your sorry butts right off the Ponderosa.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad.  Dad, we're sorry.

speaker: Niles
text: Very sorry.  [_Martin goes into the kitchen leaving the boys alone with their thoughts._]

speaker: Frasier
text: He's back on the Cartwrights again.  You know, some day we really should ask him just who the hell they are?  You know, Niles, one thing just really bugs me.  Houghton is going to leave here today thinking we're just a couple of inarticulate simpletons.

speaker: Niles
text: What with those pithy comments we made about his masterpiece.  Great.  "Wow."

speaker: Frasier
text: We'll go down in history with the same baboon who first read "Hamlet" and told Shakespeare "My goodness.  What a parchment turn!"

speaker: Niles
text: It's not too late.  He hasn't left yet.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes.  We could still say something to show him that we appreciated the full complexity of his work.  [_Houghton emerges from the bathroom._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Mr. Houghton, you know, there is one further thing I'd like to add about your book.

speaker: Houghton
text: Yeah?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's the way you modulated into the second person narrative during the flashback scene.  Frankly, it beggars anything Faulkner attempted.

speaker: Houghton
text: Really?  That's very flattering.

speaker: Niles
text: Wait, I have one too.  The way you so skilfully mirrored the structure of Dante's "Divine Comedy" was inspired.

speaker: Houghton
text: Really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, yes.  But the inferno of the bordello...

speaker: Niles
text: Which we noticed had exactly nine rooms!

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh-huh.  To the purgatory of the assembly line and finally to the paradise of the farm.

speaker: Houghton
text: You both saw that?

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, it practically jumped off the page.

speaker: Houghton
text: Well, that's very perceptive of you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, thank you.  Our turn to be flattered.

speaker: Houghton
text: You're absolutely right.  This whole book is crap!

speaker: Niles
text: Beg your pardon?

speaker: Houghton
text: How could I be so blind?  I lifted the entire structure from Dante.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, you mean you weren't going for that.

speaker: Houghton
text: Of course not.  This confirms my worst fear.  I have nothing original left to say.  I'm an empty shell.  I was a fool to think I had a second book in me. [_reading from his manuscript_] "The winters were harsh on the farm."  Well, here's something to warm them up. [_starts throwing the pages into the fire_]

speaker: Martin
text: [_coming in from the kitchen_] What's going on here?

speaker: Houghton
text: You're both right.  I'm a talentless hack who got lucky once.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, we didn't say that.

speaker: Martin
text: You're not listening to these two, are you?

speaker: Houghton
text: Look at this trash.  It won't even burn.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it's a fireplace, you see.  It's not well ventilated.

speaker: Houghton
text: This book doesn't belong in a fireplace.  It belongs in the gutter with the rest of society's garbage.  [_Houghton heads out to the balcony followed swiftly by Martin, Frasier and Niles, all protesting vehemently.  However it is of no use and Houghton throws the entire manuscript over the railing and out onto the streets below._]

speaker: Houghton
text: I want to thank you two.  If I had published that book my reputation would have been destroyed.  At least now I'm left with a shred of dignity.  [_Houghton walks off but unfortunately, given his last speech, a page is stuck to his shoe, which he doesn't notice.  Niles goes to say something but Frasier stops him._]

speaker: Martin
text: Happy?  Hey, Ted.  Wait up.  [_Martin follows Houghton outside leaving the boys alone once again._]

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, we've destroyed a man's life.

speaker: Niles
text: Not to mention depriving future generations of a work of art.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, you know on the other hand, had he actually published it the critics surely would have noticed that Dante parallel.

speaker: Niles
text: Hmm.  If he felt bad hearing it from us, imagine how he would have felt reading it in the "New York Review of Books."

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh God, yes.  With his fragile ego he would have been completely devastated.

speaker: Niles
text: Who knows what he might have done?

speaker: Frasier
text: You know, Niles... we saved that man's life.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I think you're right. [_then_] On the other hand...

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't go there!

speaker: Niles
text: See, that's why you're the older brother.  [_End of Act 2_]
